â
The '''2011 Egyptian protests''' are a series of street demonstrations, protests, and acts of [[civil disobedience]] that began in [[Egypt]] on 25 January 2011, a day selected by [[April 6 Youth Movement]] organizers<ref name="nyt-fahim">{{cite news |first=Kareem |last=Fahim |coauthors=Mona El-Nagaar |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html |title=Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarakâs Rule |publisher=The New York Times | date=2011-01-25 | accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> to coincide with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]] holiday.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/> While localised protests had been common in previous years, the 2011 protests have been the largest demonstrations seen in Egypt since the [[1977 Egyptian Bread Riots]] and "unprecedented" in scope,<ref name="Dan Murphy 0125">{{cite news |last=Murphy |first=Dan |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0125/Inspired-by-Tunisia-Egypt-s-protests-appear-unprecedented |title=Inspired by Tunisia, Egypt's protests appear unprecedented |publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> drawing participants from a variety of socio-economic backgrounds and faiths.<ref name="nyt-fahim"/>
+
The '''2011 Egyptian protests''' are a series of street demonstrations, protests, and acts of [[civil disobedience]] that began in [[Egypt]] on 25 January 2011, a day selected by [[April 6 Youth Movement]] organizers<ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/april-6-youth-movement-calls-massive-demonstration-friday|title=April 6 youth movement calls for massive demonstration on Friday|publisher=Almasry Alyoum|date=2011-01-27|accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref><ref name="nyt-fahim">{{cite news |first=Kareem |last=Fahim |coauthors=Mona El-Nagaar |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html |title=Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarakâs Rule |publisher=The New York Times | date=2011-01-25 | accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> to coincide with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]] holiday.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/> While localised protests had been common in previous years, the 2011 protests have been the largest demonstrations seen in Egypt since the [[1977 Egyptian Bread Riots]] and "unprecedented" in scope,<ref name="Dan Murphy 0125">{{cite news |last=Murphy |first=Dan |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0125/Inspired-by-Tunisia-Egypt-s-protests-appear-unprecedented |title=Inspired by Tunisia, Egypt's protests appear unprecedented |publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> drawing participants from a variety of socio-economic backgrounds and faiths.<ref name="nyt-fahim"/>
The demonstrations and [[riot]]s occurred in the weeks after the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|Tunisian uprising]], with many protesters carrying Tunisian flags as a symbol of their influence.<ref>{{cite news |last=Eltahawy |first=Mona |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/25/AR2011012507200.html |title=Will Egypt's protests go the way of Tunisia's revolution? |publisher=Washington Post |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> Grievances for Egyptian protesters have focused on legal and political issues<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1473531/Q&A--What-s-behind-the-unrest- |title=Q&A: What's behind the unrest? |publisher=SBS |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> including [[police brutality]],<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces">{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110125-egypt-braces-nationwide-protests |title=Egypt braces for nationwide protests |author=AFP |publisher=France24 |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> [[Emergency law in Egypt|state of emergency]] laws,<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/> lack of [[free elections]] and [[freedom of speech|free speech]],<ref name="alarabiya-plans"/> and [[Political corruption|corruption]],<ref name="alarabiya-plans">{{cite news |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/01/27/135207.html |title=Egypt activists plan biggest protest yet on Friday |publisher=Al Arabiya |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> as well as economic issues including high [[unemployment]],<ref name="tna">{{cite news |url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/8894-1007-53-Egypt_protests_a_ticking_time_bomb_Analysts |title=Egypt protests a ticking time bomb: Analysts |author=AFP |publisher=The New Age |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> [[food inflation|food price inflation]],<ref name="tna"/> and low [[minimum wages]].<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/><ref name="tna"/> Demands from protest organizers included rights of [[freedom]] and [[justice]], the end of the [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime, and a new government that represents the interests of the Egyptian people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/egyptian-activists-action-plan-translated/70388/ |title=Egyptian Activists' Action Plan: Translated |publisher=The Atlantic |date=2011-01-27}}</ref>
The demonstrations and [[riot]]s occurred in the weeks after the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|Tunisian uprising]], with many protesters carrying Tunisian flags as a symbol of their influence.<ref>{{cite news |last=Eltahawy |first=Mona |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/25/AR2011012507200.html |title=Will Egypt's protests go the way of Tunisia's revolution? |publisher=Washington Post |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> Grievances for Egyptian protesters have focused on legal and political issues<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1473531/Q&A--What-s-behind-the-unrest- |title=Q&A: What's behind the unrest? |publisher=SBS |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> including [[police brutality]],<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces">{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110125-egypt-braces-nationwide-protests |title=Egypt braces for nationwide protests |author=AFP |publisher=France24 |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> [[Emergency law in Egypt|state of emergency]] laws,<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/> lack of [[free elections]] and [[freedom of speech|free speech]],<ref name="alarabiya-plans"/> and [[Political corruption|corruption]],<ref name="alarabiya-plans">{{cite news |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/01/27/135207.html |title=Egypt activists plan biggest protest yet on Friday |publisher=Al Arabiya |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> as well as economic issues including high [[unemployment]],<ref name="tna">{{cite news |url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/8894-1007-53-Egypt_protests_a_ticking_time_bomb_Analysts |title=Egypt protests a ticking time bomb: Analysts |author=AFP |publisher=The New Age |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> [[food inflation|food price inflation]],<ref name="tna"/> and low [[minimum wages]].<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/><ref name="tna"/> Demands from protest organizers included rights of [[freedom]] and [[justice]], the end of the [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime, and a new government that represents the interests of the Egyptian people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/egyptian-activists-action-plan-translated/70388/ |title=Egyptian Activists' Action Plan: Translated |publisher=The Atlantic |date=2011-01-27}}</ref>
